course.subject: math
course.title: CSE Calculus I
course.description: Differentiation of single-variable functions, basics of integration of single-variable functions. Applications: max-min, related rates, area, curve-sketching. Use of calculator, cooperative learning.
course.prerequisites: CSE or pre-bioprod concurrent registration is required (or allowed) in biosys engn (PRE), background in [precalculus, geometry, visualization of functions/graphs], instr consent; familiarity with graphing calculators recommende

course.subject: physics
course.title: Introductory Physics for Science and Engineering I
course.description: Use of fundamental principles to solve quantitative problems. Motion, forces, conservation principles, structure of matter. Applications to mechanical systems.
course.prerequisites: concurrent registration is required (or allowed) in Math 1271 or concurrent registration is required (or allowed) in Math 1371 or concurrent registration is required (or allowed) in Math 1571

course.subject: writing
course.title: University Writing
course.description: Drafting, revising, editing. Academic genres. Critical reading, rhetorical analysis for principles of audience, purpose, and argumentative strategies. Emphasizes electronic/print library. Critical analysis, annotated bibliography, research paper.

course.subject: math
course.title: Calculus II
course.description: Techniques of integration. Calculus involving transcendental functions, polar coordinates, Taylor polynomials, vectors/curves in space, cylindrical/spherical coordinates. Use of calculators, cooperative learning.
course.prerequisites: Grade of at least C- in [1371 or equiv], CSE or pre-Bioprod/Biosys Engr

course.subject: physics
course.title: Introductory Physics for Science and Engineering II
course.description: Use of fundamental principles to solve quantitative problems. Motion, forces, conservation principles, fields, structure of matter. Applications to electromagnetic phenomena.
course.prerequisites: 1301W, concurrent registration is required (or allowed) in Math 1272 or Math 1372 or Math 1572

course.subject: chemistry
course.title: Chemical Principles I
course.description: Atomic theory, periodic properties of elements. Thermochemistry, reaction stoichiometry. Behavior of gases, liquids, and solids. Molecular/ionic structure/bonding. Organic chemistry and polymers. energy sources, environmental issues related to energy use.
course.prerequisites: Grade of at least C- in [1011 or 1015] or [passing placement exam, concurrent registration is required (or allowed) in 1065]; intended for science or engineering majors; concurrent registration is required (or allowed) in 1065; registration for 1065 must precede registration for 1061

course.subject: chemistry
course.title: Chemical Principles I Laboratory
course.description: Basic laboratory skills while investigating physical and chemical phenomena closely linked to lecture material. Experimental design, data collection and treatment, discussion of errors, and proper treatment of hazardous wastes.
course.prerequisites: concurrent registration is required (or allowed) in 1061

course.subject: math
course.title: CSE Multivariable Calculus and Vector Analysis
course.description: Derivative as linear map. Differential/integral calculus of functions of several variables, including change of coordinates using Jacobians. Line/surface integrals. Gauss, Green, Stokes theorems. Use of computer technology.
course.prerequisites: [1272 or 1282 or 1372 or 1572] w/grade of at least C-, CSE or pre-Bioprod/Biosys Engr

course.subject: industrial engineering
course.title: Foundations of Industrial and Systems Engineering
course.description: History/development of industrial/systems engineering, operations planning, quality control, human factors, resource management, financial engineering, facility location/layout, optimization, probabilistic/stochastic models, simulation, project management.

course.subject: industrial engineering
course.title: Engineering Economics
course.description: Cost/design process, cost estimation models, cash flow analysis, interest rate models, time value of money, evaluation of projects, internal rate of return, depreciation/income taxes, price changes/inflation, capital budgeting, decision making under uncertainty.

course.subject: computer science
course.title: Introduction to Computing and Programming Concepts
course.description: Fundamental programming concepts using Python language. Problem solving skills, recursion, object-oriented programming. Algorithm development techniques. Use of abstractions/modularity. Data structures/abstract data types. Develop programs to solve real-world problems.
course.prerequisites: concurrent registration is required (or allowed) in MATH 1271 or concurrent registration is required (or allowed) in MATH 1371 or concurrent registration is required (or allowed) in MATH 1571H or instr consent

course.subject: math
course.title: CSE Linear Algebra and Differential Equations
course.description: Linear algebra: basis, dimension, eigenvalues/eigenvectors. Differential equations: linear equations/systems, phase space, forcing/resonance, qualitative/numerical analysis of nonlinear systems, Laplace transforms. Use of computer technology.
course.prerequisites: [1272 or 1282 or 1372 or 1572] w/grade of at least C-, CSE or pre-Bio Prod/Biosys Engr

course.subject: industrial engineering
course.title: Statistics, Quality, and Reliability
course.description: Random variables/probability distributions, statistical sampling/measurement, statistical inferencing, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, single/multivariate regression, design of experiments, statistical quality control, quality management, reliability, maintainability.

course.subject: economics
course.title: Principles of Micoeconomics
course.description: Microeconomic behavior of consumers, firms, and markets in domestic and world economy. Demand and supply. Competition and monopoly. Distribution of income. Economic interdependencies in the global economy. Effects of global linkages on individual decisions.
course.prerequisites: knowledge of plane geometry and advanced algebra

course.subject: industrial engineering
course.title: Optimization I
course.description: Optimization models, data/solutions, linear programming, simplex method, duality theory, sensitivity analysis, network optimization models, integer programming.

course.subject: industrial engineering
course.title: Quality Engineering and Reliability
course.description: Quality engineering/management, economics of quality. Statistical process control, reliability, maintain ability, availability.

course.subject: industrial engineering
course.title: Optimization II
course.description: Classifying optimization models. Modeling binary variables, branch and bound. Shortest path. Minimum spanning tree. Nonlinear programming, global and local optima, optimality conditions. Algebraic modeling languages and optimization solvers.

course.subject: industrial engineering
course.title: Stochastic Models
course.description: Models for describing/evaluating random systems. Formulating/analyzing stochastic models for business. Discrete-time/continuous-time Markov chains. Poisson processes. Markovian/non-Markovian queueing theory. Inventory management, manufacturing, reliability.

course.subject: industrial engineering
course.title: Production and Inventory Control
course.description: Methods for managing production, inventory, supply chain operations. Demand forecasting, inventory control, production planning/scheduling, supply chain coordination, manufacturing flow analysis. Implications of emerging technologies, business practices, government regulations.

course.subject: industrial engineering
course.title: Simulation
course.description: Introduction to techniques/tools of stochastic simulation. Applications from finance/insurance risk. Problems in inventory/queueing.

course.subject: industrial engineering
course.title: Project Management
course.description: Introduction to engineering project management. Analytical methods of selecting, organizing, budgeting, scheduling, and controlling projects. Risk management, team leadership, program management.
